intro: Khaya madagascariensis, commonly known as African teak, is a large evergreen tree native to Madagascar and parts of tropical Africa. It belongs to the family Fabaceae and is characterized by its smooth, greyish bark and compound leaves with 8–16 pairs of elliptical leaflets. The tree produces small, yellowish flowers followed by elongated, woody pods containing flat, brown seeds. It is valued for its durable, heavy wood, which is used in furniture, construction, and musical instruments. Due to overharvesting and habitat loss, it is also considered an endangered species.
